comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: This is the McGarel Town Hall, Larne, Co Antrim. Google Street View The building is French Gothic, designed (1868-1870) by Alexander Tate and paid for by one of Larne's benefactors, Charles McGarel, JP, DL (1788-1876). McGarel was originally from Magheramorne, Larne, and had emigrated to Demerara, in Guyana, and made a fortune in the sugar industry.

comment._content: The stonework looks new here - not much evidence of 'guano', unless the neighbours recently scraped the building clean and bottled it.  So near the building date c.1870?  I see the clock is not yet there.   From my experience of dating photos of public buildings in NSW, often the clocks were fitted years later for some reason,  probably financial.  How do you find that out in Ireland?

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
President Millard Fillmore, in the State of the Union Address, December 2, 1850
 
"Peruvian guano has become so desirable an article to the agricultural interest of the United States that it is the duty of the Government to employ all the means properly in its power for the purpose of causing that article to be imported into the country at a reasonable price. Nothing will be omitted on my part toward accomplishing this desirable end. I am persuaded that in removing any restraints on this traffic the Peruvian Government will promote its own best interests, while it will afford a proof of a friendly disposition toward this country, which will be duly appreciated."

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: The Guano peddlers are at #2 Main Street. If anyone has access to a copy of Bassett's 1888 Directory (the "Book of Antrim"), it might be good to confirm, however, this transcription of the 1880 Belfast /Ulster directory strongly suggests that it's "Fleming & Co". Listed in earlier directories as "Alexander Fleming", the 1880 entry lists "Fleming & Co., seedsmen, grocers, provision merchants, house furnishing ironmongery, paints, oils, delf, etc., 2 Main Street". (Interesting to note that the market was so demanding that the same 1880 directory lists no fewer than 37 "Guano and Seed Merchants" in Londonderry). Doesn't really help with the date much, as the Fleming's seem to be listed in the 1877 and 1880 directories. They were definitely gone by 1901 however. However census points to other Foster's on the street. (Though these were drapers and may have been unrelated).

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] What you often find (and I'm not sure if this is the case here) is that these towers might have had one clock initially. With the other clock faces/etc being added later. For cost/scope reasons. (There are now clocks on at least three faces of the Larne Town Hall tower. Likely it was opened with one on the Cross Street face. Or perhaps none at all).

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: A trawl on the internet has provided no real assistance as to when the clock was installed - there was one in place in 1900 when Frances Frith took this picture - at least on the side of the tower that faces Pound Street. But as this was 30 years after the building had opened you might expect the clock (or clocks) to be in place by then. That doesn't help with dating the photo above.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content:
I also wrote to Larne Tourism Office of Larne Borough Council and got a very prompt reply from Jenny Caldwell, Heritage Officer:
"The beautiful clock tower which is very much a prominent feature of the building was added at a later date in October 1876. The five large bells were made by Messrs John Taylor & Co., Bell founders of Loughborough; Messrs John Moore and Sons, Clerkenwell, Close, London constructed the clock and its tower".
So although the building was opened 25 Aug 1870, from the note from Jenny Caldwell it would seem that the 'clock tower' was not added until Oct 1876. I am away now to track down Messrs John Moore & Sons of Clerkenwell, if possible!

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: Chris Canavan of Canavan Clockmakers has also replied to confirm that the clock mechanism (and bells) are dated 1876.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] According to this www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=119411#s17 John Moore & Sons had vacated their premises in Clerkenwell Close by 1900 but they do have a long history there www.google.ie/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&so...

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Thank you. I have established that:
The manufacturers came into existence around 1790 under the name of Handley and Moore, two men who had been apprenticed together under John Thwaites. John Moore took complete charge of the firm around 1821, when George Handley died. His sons joined him in the trade, so that by 1829 the firm was established as John Moore & Sons. Their new firm was to produce an incredible array of movements which could be found everywhere in society: libraries, ships, halls, railway waiting rooms and kitchens, as well as church towers (turret clocks). When Henry J Moore died in 1899, the firm ceased production.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Carol, I think you can safely date the photo between 1870 and 1876.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] That is good work,  well done you.  As I understand it, if the clock tower was completed in 1876, and the date of the clock mechanism is 1876 (but not yet apparent here),  then this photo must be 1876.  Or have I misunderstood something?

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: I'm not convinced the tower was built separately to the building. Suspect it was just the clock that was added later.
